turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Lobethal.
turn.2: Krummnow wanted it based on his own principles of shared property and fervent prayer.
turn.4: The Lobethal settlers rejected Krummnow's vision and legally disputed his right to the land titles.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: Many of their traditions remain to this day, although the town is not as overtly Germanic as Hahndorf or Tanunda.
turn.8: In 1845, St John's Lutheran Church was built; it is now the oldest Lutheran church building in Australia.
turn.10: A new church has been built alongside.
turn.11: What else is interesting about this article?
turn.12: The town, as with many German towns in South Australia, was built in typical Silesian Hufendorf style, with the cottages arranged in a line along the main street, and each family having a long, narrow strip of land (used for growing crops) stretching from the main street back to the village common, where all families could allow their animals to graze.
